Problem:
Consider a linear transformation of a function \\( u(x) \\) in a complex domain using a Laplace Transform, denoted as \\( \\mathcal{L}\\{u(x)\\} = U(s) \\), where \\( s \\) is a complex number. This scenario investigates the implications of the reversal of this transformation and the intervention of modifying the transform function.

If a function \\( V(s) = s U(s) \\) is used instead of \\( U(s) \\) and then is transformed back to the time domain, will the resulting \\( v(x) \\) at all points \\( x \\) be merely a derivative of \\( u(x) \\)?
Explanation: The multiplication of \\( U(s) \\) by \\( s \\) in the Laplace domain corresponds to the differentiation of \\( u(x) \\) in the time domain. Therefore, applying \\( V(s) = s U(s) \\) and inverse-transforming results in \\( v(x) \\), which is indeed the derivative of \\( u(x) \\), according to the properties of the Laplace Transform.
